## 1. US place, circa 1900
Identify the place to which the label is pointing.

:::{.v-center-container}






::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
rland_a |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf(fill = "antiquewhite1", color = "burlywood3") +
  geom_sf(data = st_buffer(rland_a, -6000), linewidth = 0.6, fill = NA, color = alpha("burlywood3", 0.4)) +
  geom_sf(data = st_buffer(rland_a, 6000), linewidth = 0.4, fill = NA, color = alpha(c("lightblue"), 0.7)) +
  geom_label_repel(data = filter(us_places, id==1), stat = "sf_coordinates", aes(label = id, geometry=geometry), color = "chocolate4", size = 7, force = 1000, seed = 42, min.segment.length = 0, arrow = arrow(length = unit(2, "mm")), fill="floralwhite", segment.size = 1) +
  labs(
  ) 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](h187_prelim1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::






:::

## 8. The US politician who advocated a program for public investment overseas was 

a) Woodrow Wilson
b) Robert Lansing
c) John Pershing
d) William J. Bryan
e) Venustiano Carranza

## 9. The "punitive expedition" was a US invasion of 

a) Russia
b) Nicaragua
c) Haiti
d) Japan
e) Mexico

## 10. W. J. Bryan wanted a US _____ in Nicaragua.

a) protectorate
b) colony
c) investment bank
d) railroad
e) university

## 11. Prior to World War I, US military strategy focused mainly on strength in the

a) Navy
b) Coast Guard
c) Air Force
d) Marines
e) Delta Force

## 12. War Plan Orange anticipated that a Japanese attack on the US would succeed in

a) the Coral Sea
b) the Philippines
c) Panama
d) Midway
e) Honolulu

## 13. The proximate cause for US entry to World War I was the 

a) German declaration of unrestricted submarine warfare
b) sinking of the *Lusitania*
c) Zimmermann telegram
d) punitive expedition
e) unannounced sinking of US ships

---

### 14. This map, modeled on one from 1897, shows why US strategists would want to build what? 

:::{.v-center-container}






::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
disp_win84 <- st_sfc(st_point(c(-100, 5)), st_point(c(-50, 30)), crs = 4326)
disp_win_trans <- st_transform(disp_win84, crs = target_crs)
disp_win_coord <- st_coordinates(disp_win_trans)

#route from London to Gatún
London <- tibble("lat" = -0.739, "lon" = 51.3026)
Gatun <- tibble("lat" = -79.55, "lon" = 9.16)
euroute <- rbind(London, Gatun)
euroute <- st_as_sf(euroute, coords = c("lat", "lon"))
euroute_path <- st_cast(st_union(euroute), "LINESTRING")
euroute_path <- st_set_crs(euroute_path, 4326)

#Route from NO to Gatun
neworleans <- tibble("lat" = -90.08, "lon" = 29.95)
noroute <- rbind(neworleans, Gatun)
noroute <- st_as_sf(noroute, coords = c("lat", "lon"))
noroute_path <- st_cast(st_union(noroute), "LINESTRING")
noroute_path <- st_set_crs(noroute_path, 4326)

#Route from NY to Cuba to Gatun 
punta_maisi <- tibble("lat" = -74.08347, "lon" = 20.14381)
# nyc <- tibble("lat" = -74.0022, "lon" = 40.4246) going to modify to clear Bahamas
nyc <- tibble("lat" = -71.5, "lon" = 40.4246)
ny_route <- rbind(nyc, punta_maisi)
ny_route <- st_as_sf(ny_route, coords = c("lat", "lon"))
ny_route_path <- st_cast(st_union(ny_route), "LINESTRING")
ny_route_path <- st_set_crs(ny_route_path, 4326)

#Route from Punta Maisi to Gatun
pm_route <- rbind(punta_maisi, Gatun)
pm_route <- st_as_sf(pm_route, coords = c("lat", "lon"))
pm_route_path <- st_cast(st_union(pm_route), "LINESTRING")
pm_route_path <- st_set_crs(pm_route_path, 4326)

path_text_size = 3

rland_a |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_sf(fill = "antiquewhite1", color = "burlywood3") +
  geom_sf(data = st_buffer(rland_a, -6000), linewidth = 0.6, fill = NA, color = alpha("burlywood3", 0.4)) +
  geom_sf(data = st_buffer(rland_a, 6000), linewidth = 0.4, fill = NA, color = alpha(c("lightblue"), 0.7)) +
geom_textsf(data = euroute_path, 
              label = "European route", 
              hjust = .1, 
              family = "Public Sans",
              fontface = "italic",
              size = path_text_size, 
              color = "black", 
              linetype = 4, 
              linewidth = 0.25) + 
  geom_textsf(data = noroute_path,
              label = "Mississippi River route", 
              hjust = .8, 
              family = "Public Sans",
              fontface = "italic",
              size = path_text_size, 
              color = "black", 
              linetype = 4, 
              linewidth = 0.25) + 
  geom_sf(data = ny_route_path, 
              linetype = 4, 
              linewidth = 0.25) + 
  geom_textsf(data = pm_route_path,
              label = "Northeast USA route", 
              hjust = .3, 
              family = "Public Sans",
              fontface = "italic",
              size = path_text_size, 
              color = "black", 
              linetype = 4, 
              linewidth = 0.25) +
  coord_sf(xlim = disp_win_coord[,'X'], ylim = disp_win_coord[,'Y'], crs = target_crs) -> q
q
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](h187_prelim1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::






:::

---

## 15. Identify the indicated US place as of 1900.

:::{.v-center-container}






::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
q +
  geom_label_repel(data = filter(us_places, name == "Puerto Rico"), stat = "sf_coordinates", aes(geometry=geometry), label = "15", color = "chocolate4", size = 7, force = 1000, seed = 42, min.segment.length = 0, arrow = arrow(length = unit(2, "mm")), fill="floralwhite", segment.size = 1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](h187_prelim1_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::







:::

---

### 16. US General Orders 100 provided that guerrillas should be treated like

  a) prisoners of war
  b) pirates
  c) noncommissioned US officers
  d) allied soldiers
  e) munitions merchants

---

### 17. The Theodore Roosevelt administration transformed the Monroe Doctrine into an assertion of US _____ power over the Americas.

  a) police
  b) diplomatic
  c) mercantile
  d) protectorate
  e) colonial

---

### 18. The Jones Act of 1916 anticipated eventual independence for

  a) Puerto Rico
  b) Haiti
  c) the Philippines
  d) Panama
  e) Cuba

---

### 19. The so-called "Gentlemen's Agreement" restricted immigration to the US from 

  a) China
  b) Japan
  c) Cuba
  d) Mexico
  e) Haiti

---

### 20. According to Silbey, the common Chinese understanding of the need for reform was summed up in the phrase 

  a) Death to the dowager, fire for the foreigners
  b) End empires here and abroad
  c) Question the Qing, expel the empires
  d) Support the Qing, exterminate the foreigners
  e) I've got mine, Jack

---

### 21. In June of 1900, Boxers massed in Beijing and laid siege to

  a) the mercantile quarter
  b) the imperial palace
  c) the Christian churches
  d) the customs house
  e) the foreign legations

---

### 22. In the case of Roger Keyes and the arsenal, Silbey wants to make a general point that colonial powers

  a) had decisions forced on them by distant events
  b) had precise control over distant events
  c) did not wish to suppress a rebellion in China
  d) were constrained by religious conviction
  e) decided to open trade relations with Indonesia

---

### 23. At the Paris Peace Conference, Japan proposed 

  a) an end to the gold standard
  b) a system of protectorates
  c) a new nation, Czechoslovakia
  d) a racial equality clause
  e) a quarantine of Russia
  
---

### 24. The US Pacific strategy aimed primarily at the annexation of

  a) Hawai`i
  b) trade
  c) the Philippines
  d) China
  e) Japan
  
---

### 25. The 1919 peace treaty with Germany was the Treaty of 

  a) St. Germain
  b) Versailles
  c) the Trianon
  d) Sacré Cœur
  e) Vienna
